item.title: Thai Attorneys Drop Royal Insult Charge Against US Academic
item.description: Thai attorneys have dropped royal insult charges against a US academic citing a lack of evidence, almost two months after he was detained and stripped of his job at a local university.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Kutty Abraham

media:content.media:description: A group of foreign tourists walk along the walls of the Royal Palace in Bangkok, Thailand, on Saturday, Feb. 19, 2022. Thailand’s economy looks set to expand by 1.8% year on year in the fourth quarter. Photographer: Luke Duggleby/Bloomberg

item.title: Vietnam Blocks Printed Copies of The Economist Over To Lam Cover
item.description: A printed edition of The Economist magazine with Vietnam’s Communist Party General Secretary To Lam on the front cover has been blocked from distribution in the country, in the latest sign of the government’s tightening control over the media.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Stevens

media:content.media:description: To Lam in Hanoi on May 26. Photographer: Chalinee Thirasupa/POOL/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Israel Approves New Settlements to Obstruct Palestinian State
item.description: Israel will build 22 new settlements in the West Bank including some along its eastern border with Jordan to strengthen its grip on the territory and block the establishment of an independent Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: Galit Altstein

media:content.media:description: A Palestinian laborer works at a construction site in the Israeli settlement of Maale Adumim, in the West Bank in February 2024.

item.title: Musk Exits DOGE Leaving Threadbare Agencies and Strained Workers
item.description: The full effects of a drastic cost-cutting campaign are coming into focus as its billionaire architect departs from the government
item.dc:creator: Ted Mann

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk

item.title: Complex Mexican Vote May Be a Double-Edged Sword
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: A volunteer holds a sample ballot in front of the Supreme Court of Justice of the Nation in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Mexican voters for the first time will elect their judges in a process involving thousands of little-known candidates that could drastically change the balance of power in the country. Photographer: Stephania Corpi/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Boosts Military Push Against China With US Stand Vague
item.description: Japan is stepping up efforts to deter China’s military ambitions in the Asia-Pacific as Tokyo and other US partners seek clarity from the Trump administration about its plans to counter Beijing’s power in the region.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Mari Kiyohara

media:content.media:description: Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba, center, during his visit to the Philippine Coast Guard Headquarters in Metro Manila, the Philippines, on April 30.

item.title: Portugal’s Far-Right Shatters 50-Year Two Party Dominance
item.description: During Portugal’s recent election campaign, far-right Chega leader Andre Ventura argued that the two centrist parties that have ruled the nation for half a century have failed to increase living standards, control immigration and end systemic corruption.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: Andre Ventura

item.title: South Africa’s EFF Asks Court to Stop Proposed Fuel Levy Hike
item.description: South Africa’s leftist Economic Freedom Fighters filed court papers in a bid to halt a proposed increase in fuel levies, the latest twist in a months-long tussle over the annual budget.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: A gas station in the Alberton district of Johannesburg

item.title: China Defense Minister Skips Singapore Forum Attended by Hegseth
item.description: China indicated it will not send its top military diplomat to a key defense forum in Asia for the first time since 2019, preventing a potential first encounter with US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Lucille Liu

media:content.media:description: Dong Jun, China's defense minister, inspects an honor guard in Singapore, on Thursday, May 30, 2024. Dong is visiting Singapore from May 29 to June 3 to attend the Shangri-La Dialogue, according to a social media post published by China's Ministry of Defense.

item.title: Farmers Press Trump for Biofuels Boost to Counter Tariff Losses
item.description: After losing their biggest export market due to Donald Trump’s trade wars, US farmers are now counting on the president’s support for biofuels to prevent their next crop from piling up in storage.
item.dc:creator: Kim Chipman, Alicia Diaz, Erin Ailworth, Ilena Peng

media:content.media:description: A combine harvester cuts, threshes, and cleans soybeans during a harvest in Waynesfield, Ohio. Photographer: Matthew Hatcher/Bloomberg

item.title: Marcos Promotes Police Officer Who Led Duterte Arrest
item.description: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. promoted a police officer who led the historic arrest of his predecessor, Rodrigo Duterte, as part of a broader government reorganization following a setback in recent elections.
item.dc:creator: Ditas B Lopez, Neil Jerome Morales

media:content.media:description: General Nicolas Torre attends a hearing of the Committee of Foreign Affairs following the International Criminal Court (ICC) arrest of former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte, at the Senate in Pasay, metro Manila on March 20.

item.title: Starmer to Accuse Farage of Truss-Style ‘Fantasy’ Economics
item.description: Keir Starmer is expected to hit back at what he describes as Nigel Farage’s “fantasy economics” in the latest sign that the Labour prime minister believes he must act to arrest Reform UK’s surge in opinion polls.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: US to Revoke Chinese Student Visas in Escalating Crackdown
item.description: The US plans to start “aggressively” revoking visas for Chinese students, Secretary of State Marco Rubio said, escalating the Trump administration’s push for greater scrutiny of foreigners attending American universities.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams, Ryan Chua, Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: Photo by Brooks Kraft LLC/Corbis via Getty Images)

item.title: China Calls US Plan to Revoke Student Visas ‘Discriminatory’
item.description: China blasted the Trump administration’s move to revoke the visas of Chinese students in the US, underscoring the fragility of a recent steadying of ties between the world’s largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: University students in the US.

item.title: Libya’s State Oil Company Faces Shutdown Threat After Gunmen Storm HQ
item.description: Libya’s eastern government said it may shut down oil production and exports in protest after a militia aligned with rival authorities in the west stormed the state-oil company’s headquarters.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany

item.title: Trump’s Trade Strategy Upended After Court Blocks Global Tariffs
item.description: President Donald Trump’s tariff strategy has been thrown into turmoil after a US court issued a rare rebuke blocking many of the import taxes he has threatened and imposed on other countries.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan, Erik Larson, Laura Curtis

item.title: Japan’s Akazawa Heads to US for Latest Round of Tariff Talks
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa is headed to Washington for his fourth round of trade negotiations with the US, signaling that talks will continue as expected despite a US court ruling that declared the tariffs illegal.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Ryosei Akazawa

item.title: Poland’s World-Beating Rally Is Facing an Election Reality Check
item.description: Revved-up Polish markets will be put to the test this weekend as voters head to the polls in the biggest challenge facing Premier Donald Tusk.
item.dc:creator: Selcuk Gokoluk, Wojciech Moskwa

item.title: Lutnick Defends US Tariffs as Key to India-Pakistan Ceasefire
item.description: The ceasefire between India and Pakistan earlier this month was only achieved after US President Donald Trump offered the two countries trading access, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said in a legal submission defending the White House’s tariff policy.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick Photographer: Chris Kleponis/CNP

item.title: Singapore Premier Warns Lawmakers on Perceptions of Impropriety
item.description: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong told ruling party lawmakers to be vigilant in their interactions to avoid perceptions of impropriety.
item.dc:creator: Chanyaporn Chanjaroen

media:content.media:description: Lawrence Wong Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Delaware AG Seeking Bank to Advise on OpenAI Restructuring
item.description: Delaware’s attorney general is planning to hire an investment bank that would advise her office as it examines OpenAI’s restructuring plans aimed at drawing more investors, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Willmer, Malathi Nayak

item.title: Musk Departs US Government With His Business Empire in Flux
item.description: Billionaire Elon Musk said Wednesday that his time as formal adviser to President Donald Trump is coming to a close, raising questions about the future of the Department of Government Efficiency effort he spearheaded.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Jennifer A Dlouhy, Dana Hull

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk

item.title: Spain Bets on 1 Million Migrants to Keep Its Economy Growing
item.description: The country is bucking European trends with its most ambitious migration push to date, including a proposal for a “mass regularization” of undocumented foreign workers.
item.dc:creator: Laura Millan, Yinka Ibukun, Daniel Basteiro

item.title: Why Poland’s Election Is a Barometer for Europe’s Populist Wave
item.description: Poland’s presidential election will determine whether the country can overhaul controversial judicial reforms and remain a reliable partner in the European Union after nearly a decade of divisive right-wing populism.
item.dc:creator: Piotr Skolimowski, Wojciech Moskwa

media:content.media:description: Poland’s presidential palace in Warsaw

item.title: Trump’s Global Tariffs Deemed Illegal, Blocked by Trade Court
item.description: The vast majority of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs were deemed illegal and blocked by the US trade court, dealing a major blow to a pillar of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump

item.title: RFK Jr. Slams Medical Journals, Floats In-House Publishing Plan
item.description: US Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said he may bar government scientists from publishing in top medical journals, accusing publications like The New England Journal of Medicine of being “corrupt” and beholden to pharmaceutical companies.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gale

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: US Ally South Korea Set to Improve China Ties If Lee Wins Vote
item.description: A win for the left-of-center frontrunner in South Korea’s presidential election would likely herald more caution by Seoul over taking sides in US-China rivalry, a new effort to draw North Korea into dialogue and the potential for tension with Japan.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae-myung speaks at a campaign event in Uijeongbu on May 20.

item.title: Eric Trump Says He’d Love to See Some Big Banks ‘Go Extinct’
item.description: Eric Trump told attendees at a cryptocurrency conference that he wants some big banks to “go extinct,” echoing complaints from other members of the Trump family about the traditional financial system.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif

media:content.media:description: Eric Trump on May 28.

item.title: Economists Cut Thai, Malaysian Growth Forecasts on Trade Turmoil
item.description: Economists have slashed forecasts for growth in Malaysia and Thailand as the export-dependent economies grapple with US President Donald Trump’s global trade war.
item.dc:creator: Tomoko Sato

media:content.media:description: Malaysia’s central bank said earlier this month that it has policy room to act, as it expects growth to fall below the official forecast this year.

item.title: Australia Aims to Avoid Panama Repeat in China Port Showdown
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is confronting a fresh diplomatic dilemma with China: How to fulfill a pledge to regain control of a strategic port without jeopardizing improved relations with his country’s largest trading partner.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: The Port of Darwin in Australia.
